Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has regenerated after his ordeal with the Cybermen and energy- draining Mondas. Ben and Polly watched him change into a younger person.

Dialogue.Line: His face, his hair, look at it.
He's breathing, and the Tardis seems to be normal.
Ben, what are we going to do? We can't just leave the Doctor there.
What, him? The Doctor?
Well, that's who came through the doors. There was no one else outside. Ben, do you remember what he said in the tracking room? Something about 'This old body of mine is wearing a bit thin.'
So he gets himself a new one?
Well, yes.
Oh, do me a favour.
Then whatever happened, happened in here.
But it's impossible.
Not so long ago we'd have been saying that about a lot of things.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man on the floor moans and opens his eyes. As he struggles to sit up, a searing pain nearly cripples him. Clutching his head, he stares wildly at Ben and Polly, his vision blurred. We hear the thumping of his headache, or is it heartbeat?

Dialogue.Line: Stop. Stop. Concentrate on one thing. One thing.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man turns his attention to the Tardis console, focusing on the controls. The thumping becomes slower and softer. At last his vision clears. The man removes his hands from his face and looks around him, his features brightening in relief.

Dialogue.Line: It's over. (chuckles) It's over.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man scrambles to his feet, wobbling unsteadily. Ben and Polly watch but make no attempt to help as he circles the Tardis console as if reacquainting himself with the controls. His clothes hang off his slight frame, much too big, and he struggles to unfasten the heavy cloak that threatens to trip him up. As he does so, an ornate ring drops to the floor.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the Tardis engine springs to life and dematerialises, the man raises his hands to his face once more, feeling his features as if they belonged to a stranger. Polly moves to pick up the fallen ring, eyeing the newcomer with open curiosity and a little unease. The little man makes his way over to a storage chest, his stiff-legged gait reminding Polly of a small child learning to walk. He trips, but recovers quickly.

Dialogue.Line: The muscles are still a bit tight.
What are we going to do?
It is the Doctor. I know it is. I think.
It's not only his face that's changed. He doesn't even act like him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The stranger is rummaging through the contents of the chest.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, it's time we sorted this out. Now look here!
Hold that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He hands Ben a mirror.

Dialogue.Line: Tilt it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man gazes intently at his reflection. The face in the mirror has a mop of black hair and dark green eyes. Momentarily the image blurs and changes to that of an older, white-haired man before changing back again. Apparently satisfied, the man turns his attention back to the storage chest.

Dialogue.Line: Have you done with this?
Put it down. Put it down.
Now what's the game?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man turns, cheerfully brandishing an ornamental dagger.

Dialogue.Line: Ah! The Crusades, from Saladin. The Doctor was a great collector, wasn't he?
But you're the Doctor.
Oh, I don't look like him.
Who are we?
Don't you know?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man rummages further and pulls out a piece of dull silver metal. His look of mischief fades as the object triggers a very clear memory.

Dialogue.Line: Extermination.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man stuffs the metal into his pocket. His concern turns to delight as he unearths a magnifying glass. He begins a careful study of his hands.

Dialogue.Line: Ah. Very good. Nails need growing.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben takes the Doctor's ring from Polly.

Dialogue.Line: Now look, the Doctor always wore this. So if you're him, it should fit now, shouldn't it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And slips it on the man's finger. It's far too big.

Dialogue.Line: There. That settles it.
I'd like to see a butterfly fit into a chrysalis case after it's spread its wings.
Then you did change!
Life depends on change and renewal.
Oh, so that's it. You've been renewed, have you?
I've been renewed, have I? That's it. I've been renewed. It's part of the Tardis. Without it, I couldn't survive. Come here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Unexpectedly, the man rounds on Polly.

Dialogue.Line: Come here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Still rather nervous of this strange interloper, Polly steps closer.

Dialogue.Line: The Doctor kept a diary, didn't he?
Yes.
I thought so. I wonder where. I wonder where.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben and Polly watch as the man resumes his search of the chest.

Dialogue.Line: He's a very different Doctor, Ben.
Yeah, maybe. Just where do we stand, though?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man has found something else in the chest. A descant recorder. He removes it with great care and stands flexing his fingers over the holes. His expression is one of pure child-like joy, and convinces Polly that it's time for her to trust her instincts about the man's identity. He plays a little tune and dances a jig, stopping when he spots the missing diary.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tucking the recorder into his jacket, the Doctor begins to read.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, what's going to happen to us?
I think. I think we must have landed for sometime. I think it's time we went for a stroll.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor grabs a stove-pipe hat from the chest. Engrossed in his reading, he moves to the console and opens the Tardis doors.

Dialogue.Line: But you don't know where we've landed!
No, you haven't checked the oxygen or the temperature or anything!
(still reading the diary) Oxygen density 172, radiation nil, temperature 86. Strong suggestion of mercury deposits. Satisfied, Ben? Now, are you two coming or are you not?
He does know us. He said Ben. Didn't you hear him?
Yeah, I heard. But he might just have been copying you though, mightn't he?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis has landed in a misty swamp. The ground is rocky and pitted with small bubbling pools which occasionally spray a fine silver mist into the air. The Doctor wanders away, still fascinated by the contents of the diary. Strolling directly towards a small pool of mercury, he is apparently oblivious to any danger, yet manages to successfully circumnavigate the obstacle without once looking up from his reading. Suddenly realising what he's done, he stops and looks back, delighted at having outwitted the obstruction and laughs. But then he looks down and sloshes out of the watery puddle in which he is now standing.

Dialogue.Line: Are you coming, you two?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor continues on his way. After a short distance he stops once more. A boulder blocks his path. Pulling a tape measure from his pocket, he takes some extensive measurements of the rock, and scribbles some calculations on an empty page of the diary. The Doctor glances round him. The boulder stands in a clearing and he could easily walk round it, but a look of mischief crosses his face. Backing up a few steps, the Doctor looks down at his legs, flexing his knees.

Dialogue.Line: Time I put you through some tests, I think.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Breaking into a run, the Doctor successfully leap-frogs the boulder.

Dialogue.Line: Hello?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A newcomer has entered the clearing.

Dialogue.Line: Hello? Is there anyone there? Hello? Hello? Why don't they come? (sees the Doctor) Ah, so you've come at last. I'm from Earth. I'm the Examiner.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's a gun shot. The man crumples to the ground. Horrified, the Doctor's about to dive for cover then pauses and, keeping low, approaches the fallen figure. He rolls the man over, and sees that he is dead. Searching for some kind of identification, the Doctor finds a large round badge. Automatically reaching into his top pocket he pulls out a pair of wire-rimmed spectacles and puts them on. He squints at the badge and moves it backwards and forwards, trying to focus on it, yet all he can see is a misty blur. He removes the spectacles and tries again. This time the text is clear.

Dialogue.Line: Earth Examiner. Accord every access. Vulcan.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Behind the Doctor, a figure looms out of the mist, wearing an all-concealing white suit and goggles. The figure trains a pistol on the Doctor's back.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, where are you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor turns. The figure dodges out of sight. Close to the Tardis, Ben and Polly are exploring the swamp.

Dialogue.Line: Phwoar, ain't it hot.
Do you think the air's like this everywhere?
Nah, might be just around here. Don't want too many lungfuls of it, I know that. Here, when I was a kid, we used to live opposite a brewery. You could take a walk and get tipsy all in one go.
It's beautiful.
No, don't touch it, Polly.
I wasn't going to.
No, it's quicksilver. It gets through the pores. Where is the Doctor, or whatever he is, got to?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As Ben moves away, a cloud of mercury vapour catches Polly full in the face. She coughs.

Dialogue.Line: What's the matter? Hey, Polly! Hey, Doctor, wherever you are. Quick, there's something happening to Polly!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor heads back to the Tardis at a run.

Dialogue.Line: Quick! Over this way!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Pistol raised as a bludgeon, the suited figure steps out behind the Doctor and knocks him down. The Doctor grabs at the figure briefly before sinking to the ground, unconscious. Working quickly, the stranger presses something into the Doctor's palm then drags the Examiner's body away. The Doctor is left sprawled on the ground, a button clutched in his outstretched hand.
Meanwhile, Ben is trying to drag the unconscious Polly to safety. Another cloud of mercury vapour rises from the pool.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The last thing Ben sees before he passes out, is a white suited figure holding a pistol approaching fast. Some time later, a young man in a white survival suit, goggles pushed up over his head, is kneeling besides the seemingly unconscious Doctor. Another older man, similarly attired, approaches.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Quinn, there you are. What have you got there? My people have found two more of them by one of the pools.
This one's got a nasty bruise on the back of his head. Fallen over his feet and knocked himself out, I suppose.
I suppose so.
Why don't they use the kit we send them?
Yes. The other two have had a rather bad dose of fumes. The girl has, anyway.
Girl?
Yes, but she'll recover.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben and Polly are helped into the clearing by two guards.

Dialogue.Line: These comic opera guards of yours do have some uses after all.
I pick them for their physical fitness.
I thought it wasn't for their IQ. Give me a hand with the Examiner, will you.
I wonder why Earth has chosen to send an Examiner to Vulcan? Just now, I mean.
I don't know.
It's a mystery, isn't it? He isn't due for another two years.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben is recovering.

Dialogue.Line: How do you feel?
(cough) Urgh.
We saw your rocket overshoot the landing area.
Ay?
Don't worry. Most of the ships from Earth do over-shoot. I'm Quinn, Deputy Governor.
Bragen, Head of Security.
Let's get them all back, shall we? I'll take the girl.
Here, you two, help carry the Examiner.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards lift the Doctor between them.

Dialogue.Line: I suppose you Earth people can't wait to examine Lesterson's space capsule?
Ay?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben is startled as the Doctor winks slyly at him.
Lesterson is polishing an oddly shaped piece of metal. A huge space capsule dominates one side of the room. Lesterson's assistant, Janley, joins him.

Dialogue.Line: (a woman) Lesterson.
Look at this.
They've just brought in an Examiner from Earth, and a couple of assistants.
An Examiner? What's he here for?
I thought you'd know.
It's the capsule, it must be. Well, they can't stop me working on it, I'll tell you that.
Could anyone?
The Governor's always been difficult about it. But surely they wouldn't send somebody all the way from Earth just
Look, what about the meeting?
Meeting?
Yes. I've arranged everything. Can we still use the old rocket room?
Yes, I suppose so. But I do wish you wouldn't get mixed up with these pressure groups, Janley.
Well, somebody has to do something. The colony's running down and you know it.
I'm too busy.
But if we ran things, you'd have better facilities, more money. I wish you'd take an interest.

Now look, I don't mind letting you have the use of one of my rooms now and again, Janley, but don't try to involve me. This is what I find important. Two hundred years in a mercury swamp and this piece of metal that dropped from it? Look, a couple of minutes polishing and it's as good as new.
Wonderful.
Rain, damp, heat, mercury. Nothing touches this metal. No corrosion, Janley. Think of that.

Well, I hope the Examiner lets you go on with your experiment. Frankly, I doubt it. I think the Governor's brought the Examiner here to stop you opening the capsule. You should join our group, Lesterson. You might need us one day.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fully recovered, the Doctor, Ben and Polly have been left to make themselves comfortable. The Doctor is plays on his recorder.

Dialogue.Line: So the murdered man was the real Examiner?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nodding, the Doctor blows a pair of notes.

Dialogue.Line: Well, did you see who did it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Top note screech.

Dialogue.Line: The Doctor got this button though.
I think it's pretty dull around here. I don't know why we don't just go back to the Tardis.
Doctor, are you going to let them think you're the real Examiner?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two notes repeated.

Dialogue.Line: Won't that be dangerous?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two notes again.

Dialogue.Line: Look, why don't you stop blowing that thing and talk to us properly?
Ben!
Now don't you start. It's bad enough with him.
Well, he hasn't done anything.
No, that's just the trouble.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben snatches the recorder away.

Dialogue.Line: He knows what happened back at the Tardis, yet will he tell us? Will he come out and say? Will he admit to being the Doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben blows angrily into the recorder. There is a knock on the door.

Dialogue.Line: Come in!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two guards in peaked caps and dark uniforms enter, with Bragen and a large bearded man in his late fifties.

Dialogue.Line: I am Hensell, the Governor. I trust you're all feeling much better?
I've felt worse, Governor. The Governor.
If Earth had seen fit to warn us you were coming, we might possibly have been able to guide you down to the landing area.
If Earth didn't warn you we were coming, Governor, they must have had a very good reason. I wonder what it was?
Now look here, I run this Colony. I'm entitled to know why you have come to Vulcan. What is your brief?
I am the Examiner.
Why are you here?
To examine. And I intend to start my examination at once.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor darts forward and begins to examine Bragen's tunic.

Dialogue.Line: Someone's leaked reports about these Rebel groups. That's it, isn't it?
Your turn now, Governor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor turns his attention to Hensell's clothing.

Dialogue.Line: There is Lesterson's capsule.
Internal affairs are my business, Bragen. Please don't interfere.
Please go on.
The capsule. It was found in a mercury swamp. It must have been here for centuries.
Interesting. Continue.
For centuries before the Earth colony arrived. I felt it might be dangerous. It might contain bacteria.
I shall examine the capsule later. You may leave us.
I shall look forward to your report. Bragen, see that the Examiner and his party get some proper clothes, will you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hensell, Bragen, and the guards leave.

Dialogue.Line: We are wearing proper clothes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor starts playing again.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, how did he get that thing back again. That was a bit of a cheek, wasn't it, seeing if the Governor was the guy you got the button off?
Doctor? When he was talking to you, you were staring at the other man.
Yes, very rude of me, wasn't it. Terrible manners. To tell you the truth, I was studying his reaction, seeing if he agreed with the story.
Did he?
Must have a look at that capsule.
Now, you want to watch you don't take this Examiner stuff a bit too far.
Our answers must come from that mercury swamp.
'Cause at least one bloke ain't going to be fooled.
When Bragen found us, he definitely said space capsule.
Look, you're not going to fool the guy that did the real Examiner in!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A little later Bragen, accompanied by a guard, is posting a notice on a board. Quinn approaches.

Dialogue.Line: Bragen! What's all this nonsense about having to have a pass to see the Examiner?
It's the Governor's idea.
Surely it doesn't apply to me?
It's not my order, Quinn. I expect the Governor wants to keep people away from him.
It sounded like one of your red-tape ideas.
It had nothing to do with me.
Right!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Quinn strides away, practically colliding with Janley.

Dialogue.Line: Oh!
Sorry, Janley.
My fault.
Are you all right?
Yes. Lesterson's just cleared me out of his lab. Is the Examiner going to let him open the capsule?
I don't know. I'm on my way there now, if I can push past Bragen's army of lay-abouts.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Later that evening, the Doctor takes Ben and Polly to see the space capsule. The Doctor spots the piece of metal that Lesterson was polishing earlier. He picks it up and examines it, worriedly.

Dialogue.Line: Where did you get this?
It dropped from the capsule.
Dropped?

Yes, when it was being hauled into the laboratory. But, you can see, this metal could revolutionise space travel. That's why I'm insisting that we open it. Well, who knows what other marvels there may be inside?
But Lesterson, I didn't think you could open it.
Well, I have a theory. I'm convinced that the opening mechanism on the other side is either here, or here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: While Lesterson is occupied, the Doctor pulls out the piece of metal he found in the Tardis and compares the two. They are identical.

Dialogue.Line: Extermination.
Now, my theory is that I can insert a laser ray in this ridge here. The ray spreads, fuses the opening device and gets us in.
Examiner, I shall have to make it your responsibility.
A laser. Why not? It shouldn't be too difficult.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The laser fires at the first spot. Nothing happens.

Dialogue.Line: Well, we'll try the other side. (Lesterson refocuses the laser. A mechanism engages and the hatchway slides open. The Doctor and Lesterson step into the capsule.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A small brightly lit chamber. The Doctor studies the far wall. Everyone else crowds in.

Dialogue.Line: Hmm. It's a bit disappointing.
Not really. This is just an entry bay, isn't it.
Yes, I suppose so.
Well, this doesn't get us very far, does it?
Getting into the rest of the capsule will take time, Governor.
Well, can't you use that torch thing again? That must be an opening door.
I should have to measure it up and find out where the lock mechanism is.
I think we'll leave if for tonight.
Leave it for tonight? But what did we come here for?
That is my decision, Governor.
But good heavens above, man.
A hundred years you say this has been buried?
Oh, at least. Now, there must be something in the inner compartment. We shall be able to find out where it came from originally.
It didn't come from this planet Vulcan.
Oh no, no, no. The metal is quite alien.
Alien, yes. Very alien. Goodnight.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves the laboratory.

Dialogue.Line: What's he up to now?
Ben, we're not going to let him out of our sight.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben and Polly follow the Doctor from the lab.

Dialogue.Line: Well, Lesterson, you got your way. Was it worth sending for this Examiner? This idiotic Examiner?
I didn't send for him. I thought you did.
Why don't you let me talk to the Examiner, Hensell. I can find out what's he's here for.
No, no, no, no. You keep away from him. We'll leave him to work with Lesterson here. We've all got enough to do without having to worry about some amateur critic from Earth interfering.
But with five minutes
You heard what I said, Quinn. You won't mind keeping the Examiner busy, Lesterson? I don't mind what you do with him so long as you keep his nose out of our business.
Yes. All right.
All right. Well, we shall talk about it tomorrow.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Once he's alone, Lesterson returns to his workbench where he quickly realises that his metal sample has disappeared.
Later that night.

Dialogue.Line: Ben!
(waking) What?
Shh! He's in the corridor.
Who is?
The Doctor, you clod. Come on, quick!
He's going towards Lesterson's lab.
Of course. To the space capsule.
Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor steps into the deserted laboratory, which is eerily illuminated by the light glowing from the interior of the capsule. At the capsule entrance, he dips into his pockets and takes out the two pieces of metal. Ben and Polly appear in the doorway of the lab just in time to see the Doctor disappear into the capsule.

Dialogue.Line: A light. A torch, outside.
Did you see it?
Quickly, Ben, quickly!
What was it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben runs out into the laboratory to look for the torch. He soon finds a lamp with a long lead and drags it back into the capsule, unaware that he's being watched by Resno, one of Lesterson's assistants. The Doctor takes the lamp and begins checking every corner of the compartment.

Dialogue.Line: Can you answer me?
It was a sort of disembodied hand. A sort of claw. It was horrible.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor searches for a while but doesn't find anything.

Dialogue.Line: No. No, there's nothing.
You were right. There were three Daleks.
Don't you know what it was? If there were three, who moved it?
Don't ask me. Lesterson?
But he hadn't opened the capsule.
No, he said he hadn't opened it. Lets get our facts straight.
Ah ha. Excellent! Good thinking, good thinking.
Well, does that mean you think he's been inside?
Perhaps he's been experimenting on the Daleks? Ah.
But, but they're things. I, I mean they're dead. They must be!
This light is dead. Now the watch.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor flicks the torch on and off.

Dialogue.Line: Do you mean these things just need power?
Now, Lesterson's fanatic. The Governor's jealous of his own position. What does that suggest to you? Don't know. Haven't thought about it. But all is not well with this colony. Add to that one Dalek.
Oh, blimey, you don't half make mountains, don't you? One Dalek?
Yes! All that is needed to wipe out this entire colony.
Examiner? Examiner?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bragen enters.

Dialogue.Line: Bragen, don't you ever knock before you enter a room?
I'm sorry if I disturbed you. I was expecting to find the Examiner here, not you, Quinn.
Well, he's not here. You'll probably want to start snooping under the bed, so I'll leave you to it.
One moment.
Don't try your luck with me, Bragen.
On the contrary, I'm trying to avoid trouble. The Governor gave express instructions that you were not to contact the Examiner. I find you here. I'm sure you can offer some suitable explanation.
I can. But not to you.
Before you go. Oh!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Quinn shoves Bragen to the floor.

Dialogue.Line: Don't ever try to block my way again.
Guard!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As Quinn leaves a guard enters and helps Bragen to his feet.

Dialogue.Line: The Examiner is missing. He must be found immediately.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is examining the exterior of the capsule.

Dialogue.Line: Of course, the real Doctor was always going on about the Daleks.
Real Doctor?
Real Doctor? Oh, you mean the real Doctor.
Yeah, now I've seen that claw thing, well, wouldn't want to shake hands with it, let's put it that way.
Doctor, look, if they're that dangerous, what are you going to do about it?
Save my breath. Would Lesterson listen? Lesterson listen. Lesterson listen, Lesterson listen. Exercises the tongue. Try it. Lesterson listen, Lesterson listen, Lesterson listen.
Look, they think you're the Examiner, order them to destroy the Daleks. Well, chuck your weight about.
(in background) Lesterson listen, Lesterson listen, Lesterson listen, Lesterson listen, Lesterson listen, Lesterson listen. POLLY + DOCTOR: Lesterson listen, Lesterson listen, Lesterson listen...

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Behind them, Lesterson and Resno enter.

Dialogue.Line: What do you think you're doing in here?
Listen, listen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds out the Examiner's badge.

Dialogue.Line: Who gave you permission?
Read this. Aloud!
Accord every access.
Exactly! It doesn't say 'except your laboratory' anywhere does it? Unless it's in micro-print.
I should have been asked first.
What was the first thing you noticed when you looked inside that capsule?
Well, the Daleks.
You were astounded?
Yes.
Amazed?
Yes.
You didn't even give them a glance! Why? Because you'd been in there and seen them. Where is the third Dalek?
I don't know what you're talking about.
You opened up the capsule without permission. You found the inner compartment containing three Daleks. You took one of them away and you hid it!
Hid it? What, what nonsense!
May I ask what all this is about?
We opened an inner compartment in the capsule, and Lesterson had already been in there.
I don't deny that.
And he's nicked a Dalek!
Dalek?
It's the name the Examiner has given to two metal creations that I've discovered inside the capsule.
And they're dangerous. Evil.
Lumps of metal. Quite inactive.
That's what you think, mate. If you'd seen

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor's recorder silences Ben.

Dialogue.Line: I consider it my duty as a scientist to examine and investigate these objects. Now please, all of you, keep out of my laboratory. Keep your hands off my experiments!
These lumps of metal, Daleks, I want them broken up, or melted down. Up or down, I don't care which, but destroyed!
I refuse to allow it.
I'm an Earth Examiner. I demand it.
You're exceeding your authority.
Perhaps we should ask the Governor about that? I wish to see him immediately.
That might be difficult.
But not impossible. Ben, Polly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Ben, and Polly leave, followed by Bragen.

Dialogue.Line: Could he stop the experiments?
I don't know. It's none of your business. You go and get Janley and then come back here. We haven't got any time to waste. Now go on, man. Quickly, quickly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Resno leaves. Lesterson goes to the capsule and opens a hidden compartment, revealing the third Dalek.

Dialogue.Line: They won't stop me experimenting. There must be some way to bring you back to life, and I'm going to find it.
And of course you do have the right of any access.
Which is why I have a badge which says so.
Lesterson watches over his ideas like a mother hen.
If there was a bomb under this floor timed to go off in five minutes, would you ask my permission before you ripped up the floorboards? Ah ha, fruit!
Thank you.
Examiner, it's up to you of course, but I'd advise a little discretion in your investigations. It's not a very good time, just now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is generously distributing fruit from a bowl by the bedside.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you. With all these disturbances
Disturbances?

Yes, minor acts of sabotage. Rebel cliques, secret newspapers, nothing important you understand, but it keeps the Governor busy. I've no doubt he'll tell you about it himself when I arrange your meeting with him.
When will that be?
Oh, he's going on a tour of the perimeter of the colony. I'll find out if he can see you before he goes.
Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bragen leaves. Polly sits next to Ben on the bed.

Dialogue.Line: You know, it's little things like this that make it difficult to believe that you're the Doctor. The other one, I mean. The proper one. Oh, nuts, you know what I mean.
Nuts? Yes, certainly, here we are. Crackers?
You, my old china, are an out and out phony!
China. Yes, I went there once I believe. Met Marco Polo.
No, not China. China! China and plate, mate, friend.
Yes, Marco Polo, a friend. I believe he was.
Don't listen to him, Doctor. I know who you are.
Shh!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gestures Polly into silence as he listens closely to a piece of fruit he's chosen from the bowl. Gently placing the fruit on the table, he pulls a pen knife from his pocket and carefully slices the fruit in half.

Dialogue.Line: It's a

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Concealed in the middle of the fruit is a tiny listening device. Indicating that Ben and Polly should remain silent, the Doctor extracts the device, drops it to the floor and stamps down hard, crushing it.

Dialogue.Line: Well, well, a touch of the bugs. Microphones.
Someone's been listening to what we were saying!
Yes, so that's why you were messing about and talking nonsense.
I never talk nonsense.
Ahem.
Well, hardly never.
Well, they certainly believe in making us at home, don't they?
At first, I thought there might be more than one.
Here, I bet old Charlie Bragen did it.
Charlie?
Well Fred wouldn't suit him, would it.
If he did do it, do you think it was his own idea? I mean, he could have been under orders.
You mean from the Governor? Ah, I don't know. What do you think, Doctor?
Oh, yes. Yes of course. Let's consider this button for a moment. It's the only clue we've got to the murderer of the Examiner. The real Examiner.
And who asked for him to come?
Well, Lesterson's crackers about that capsule. He wouldn't want anyone nosing about.
Bragen said the Governor's been having trouble.
No, rule him out. Governors are all the same. He wouldn't ask for help. If he sent the word it would look as if he couldn't do the job properly.
Yes.
Oh, well, I vote we go back to the Tardis. I've had enough of this dump.
Have you? What about the Daleks?
Well, they're dead.
Well, what about that thing we saw in the capsule? That was alive all right.
Yeah, I can't explain that.
I can. And that's why we have to stay.
Ugly-looking brutes, aren't they?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janley and Resno are wiring up the Dalek for testing.

Dialogue.Line: What's he want to muck about with them for? Leave well alone, that's what I say.
You're a fine one to be a research assistant. Leave well alone. There'll be no progress on this planet with people like you around.

We're doing all right as we are. Or we were until your lot came along stirring things up. You won't get away with it, you know. The Governor knows all about you rebels. He'll smash the lot of you when he's ready.
Governor?
Yeah, the Governor!
He couldn't smash

Will you be quiet! Where do you both think you are? This is a scientific laboratory. Kindly keep your politics out of it. Come on, Resno, man, get on with it. We haven't got all day. We've got to get this working before the Examiner stops us. He's got some phobia about these, these Daleks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is sitting on the bed clutching his diary.

Dialogue.Line: I know the misery they cause, the destruction. But there's something else more terrible. Something I can only half remember.
Doctor, what was it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A knock at the door. Bragen enters.

Dialogue.Line: Well? Where is the Governor? What did he say?
He sends his apologies, Examiner. He can't see you tonight, but he hopes to see you first thing in the morning.
Well, it might not wait that long, Char, ah, Bragen.
It will have to.
Excuse me.
Where are you going?
To see the Governor, of course.
I'm afraid that's not possible. Once his door is closed, no one, not even you, Examiner, is allowed into his room.
Very well.
Thank you. Until the morning then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bragen leaves.

Dialogue.Line: What happens now?
I shall radio Earth. Governor or not, Hensell will have to listen to them. I'll get Earth to back me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Suddenly the Doctor yanks open the door. The corridor is empty.

Dialogue.Line: That's funny. I could have sworn. You stay here. I shan't be long.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As he leaves, Ben and Polly see the Doctor slip the door knob into his pocket. They laugh.

Dialogue.Line: Connecting now.
All connections responding.
Nothing at all?
No.
Are you sure?
There's nothing wrong here.
Well, let's see.
Really, if you can't trust me to read a dial.
Be quiet. All right, we'll try again. This time we'll take it up to 3.24. Got that, Janley?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Very slowly, the Dalek's sucker arm begins to rise.

Dialogue.Line: It's moving.
Now, note this, Janley. Number one attachment with sucker stick responding. Number two attachment not moving. Number three attachment with lens responding. Watch these meters, Resno.
Still responding.
Now, it's reasonable to assume that this the sucker stick acts like some kind of a hand.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janley screams.

Dialogue.Line: It's all right. Don't be alarmed. We've only introduced temporary power. We shall have to be able to open it up before we could find how it works permanently.
It's a bit frightening.
Yes. Now, I cannot think what this short stubby arm is for.
Could the lens attachment be an eye?

Yes, yes, yes, yes. Now it's quite possible that this, Dalek, now there must be some kind of directing influence. There may even be a simplified brain. Positronic, I shouldn't wonder. Oh, if only we could open it up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The sucker arm drops suddenly.

Dialogue.Line: Now what?
Everything functioning here.
Yes. Well, perhaps the power is leaking away somewhere. We'll try again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janley increases the power supply to the Dalek. The Dale's eye-stick rises slowly.

Dialogue.Line: Look at the eye-stick! It's watching us!
Don't be absurd.
It was, I tell you. I saw it.
You can't use the phrase 'watching us'. You'll have us believing that the thing has intelligence next. Now, get on with your work, man.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor finds the door ajar and the room in semi-darkness. The place is a mess. The equipment has been sabotaged and the control panel smashed. The body of the radio operator lies on the floor, unconscious. The Doctor checks he is alive and hears movement across the room.

Dialogue.Line: I know you're there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Quinn steps from the shadows.

Dialogue.Line: Examiner, thank goodness it's you. I've been trying to talk to you ever since you got here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bragen enters.

Dialogue.Line: What's happening here? You again.
What do you want?
I found the operator unconscious.
Yes, so did I. I was just looking at him when I heard someone move. It must have been you.
And those?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Quinn is holding a set of wire cutters.

Dialogue.Line: I picked them up. What is all this?
The cables have been cut.
What? This is serious. It's not just our own communications. We're cut off from Earth as well.
The only people that would want to do that are the rebels.
If those muscle boys of yours had any brains, they'd stop things like this.
Bragen, I was attacked just after I landed. This is a small souvenir I collected.
This button belongs to you, doesn't it?
Well, yes.
And you say you picked these up? I suggest that you were sabotaging the communications.
That's a lie.
Having first attacked one of the engineers. I'd detain the Governor on evidence like that.
I hope you're not thinking of detaining me, Bragen.
I've no option. I could hardly let you run around loose after this, could I? All right, guards.
I warn you, Bragen!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the guards close around him, Quinn relaxes.

Dialogue.Line: All right, you win this round, Bragen. We'll see what it looks like in front of the Governor.
The Governor will want an enquiry. May I ask what you were doing here?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Resno has set up a camera on a tripod in front of the Dalek.

Dialogue.Line: Right. I've redirected power. This time working up to 4.68. Now, Resno, you will have to dodge between the camera and your meters.
Ready.
Connecting now.
All connections responding.
Excellent.
It's working!
Excellent. Film it, film it now, Resno. And note the readings, Janley.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek's eye-stick spins around and fixes on Resno.

Dialogue.Line: It seems to be interested in you, Resno. What's the matter with you, man?
I tell you it's intelligent. It's watching me, Lesterson, weighing me up. I can sense it.
Don't be a fool.
I don't like it, I tell you. I don't know what these things can do.
No, and we never shall know, shall we, unless we take film of every reaction. Now get on with your work, man.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Reluctantly, Resno returns to the camera. Suddenly, the Dalek's gun-stick emits a blast of negative light. Resno crumples to the floor, the camera crashing down on top of him.

Dialogue.Line: Resno!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lesterson disconnects the power.

Dialogue.Line: It's all right, he isn't dead.
What happened?
Knocked out by the shock wave.
We must get him to the hospital. I'll go and get help.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lesterson leaves. Janley kneels by Resno then reaches for a dust sheet and starts to wrap the body.
The next morning, the Doctor stands at the window, deep in thought. He starts playing his recorder.

Dialogue.Line: But we've got to defend Quinn.
Yeah, I know. He's innocent until he's proved guilty. But he is guilty.
He's the Deputy Governor.
So what? I had a headmaster once who got nicked for not paying his bus fare. And then there's the motive. Don't forget the motive.
Like what, for instance?
Well, he's the Deputy Governor, right? Maybe he wants to be Governor.
Oh, that's ridiculous.
Well, the jacket button wasn't. And he was caught red-handed in the Communications room with a pair of pliers. And don't tell me he was plucking his eye-brows either.
Look, there are some people you know are all right. You just know by looking at them.
Good morning. The enquiry is about to begin. I've been sent to escort you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lesterson is preparing the Dalek for a demonstration.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, Janley.
Is it time?
Yes, yes, I think so. I feel quite excited.
So you should. It's a wonderful achievement.
Yes, yes, but the wonderful thing, Janley, is that we don't know the full scope of this experiment. Who knows where we may go from here. Who know what this Dalek may do?
It's harmless now?
Yes, yes, yes. I've removed. Oh, Resno. Have you been to see him today?
Yes, yes.
And?
He's had medical attention. He's going to be all right.
Oh good.
No one must find out about this accident. It might give the Examiner just the excuse they want, and he could stop the whole project.
Oh yes. Yes, yes, yes, you're right.
Well. Ready?
Yes. Let's go and surprise them.
So, Lesterson, they're even capable of speech.
Yes. But then, why not? After all, they have a certain intelligence.
Yes, I know, but
But it is an intelligence that we can control.
So what you want is permission to continue your experiments?
Governor, think what it would mean if we were to set it to work in the mines. It could double our production overnight.
Consider the effects it could have on our whole economy.
Yes, and the effect of that on Earth. Yes, yes, they could be very grateful.
(to Dalek) I shall stop you. I will.
All right, Lesterson, permission granted.
Permission? Permission for what?
To continue my work, Examiner.
But, but didn't you all hear what I said? The Daleks must be destroyed!
Never!
Very well. If not by my order, then by Earth's! Come Ben, Polly.
Ah, Examiner, just a moment. Tell me, why are you so against this project?
But I've told you! I realise I can't give you any proof, but you've no idea of the danger.
No.
Yes. Danger! I shall be contacting Earth just as soon as radio communications have been restored.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor glares at the Dalek.

Dialogue.Line: You're my servant, are you?
I am.
Very well. Immobilise yourself. Go on. I order it! Immediately!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek's eye-stalk droops.

Dialogue.Line: Huh!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves with Ben and Polly. The Dalek comes back to life.

Dialogue.Line: Lesterson.
Why did you stop obeying? You were given an order.
He has gone.
Then you obey only
His order was wrong. I cannot serve human beings if I am immobilised. You gave me power. Your orders are right. I serve you.
Lesterson. Lesterson, it reasons. Just how limited is its intelligence?
Now, there is no cause for concern, Governor. Just you wait until you see the amount of work it can do. And now, I'm really going to put you through your paces. Follow me, Dalek.
I obey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek follows Lesterson and Janley.

Dialogue.Line: That's it!
We should have stayed with Quinn.
Well, we couldn't have helped him, Polly, even if we'd wanted to. The Governor's already reached his verdict.
Wire. Scissors. Tape.
But he didn't murder the real Examiner. I'm sure he didn't.
Oh, well. The way I see it this lot's too busy arguing amongst themselves to do much about anything. Anyway, first things first. The Daleks are the important thing.
Ah! Congratulations, Ben!
What did I do? What did I do?
You just used your brains, that's what you did. The Daleks are the most important thing.
I still think Quinn's innocent.
How can I be in league with the rebels?
The evidence confirms it.
It was I that warned of their dangers.
As part of your overall plan.
You wouldn't even take the matter seriously.
If I was wrong then, I have a chance to rectify it now.
If that's going to be your attitude, I suggest that we
Quinn! Let us conduct this inquiry in an orderly manner. Now, the Examiner was attacked. There can be no question of that.
And the button grabbed by the Examiner was missing from your suit.
Yes, if you've got anything to add to that, you'd better say it now.
I didn't attack the man. I had no reason to. I was the one that sent for him.
You sent for him?
It was necessary. Under the circumstances, I'd hardly be likely to sabotage the radio communications.
But, but why Quinn? Why?
Because of the rebels!
The rebels. They're nothing more than one or two fanatics.
You know as well as I do that they
Unless you're trying to create trouble here to undermine the Governor's position.
Bragen, you'd better explain that.
If you're removed, who takes your place? The Deputy Governor, of course. And that's the real reason behind all this trouble, isn't it, Quinn?
Go on.
You attack the Examiner in the mercury swamp and blame it on the rebels. Then you sabotage the radio and blame that on the rebels too.
Get him out of my sight!
Hensell, before you listen to these preposterous allegations

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards drag Quinn out.

Dialogue.Line: I chose Quinn myself. I trained him for the job. Why, in a few years time, he'd have had this seat.
Sometimes, Governor, a few years is a long time to wait.
Oh, Bragen?
Governor?
You will assume Quinn's duties. As of now, you are Deputy Governor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor uses a chair to smash the outer casing of a small electrical unit he's appropriated.

Dialogue.Line: I hope you know what you're doing.
So do I. Excellent. excellent.
I thought we were after the Daleks, not this control unit you've nicked.
If only we could find a. Ah, yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Crossing to the bed, the Doctor pulls the mattress from the frame.

Dialogue.Line: He's a right little delinquent, isn't he?
Doctor, what on Earth are you up to?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor tugs at one of the metal cross straps on the bed frame until it comes loose.

Dialogue.Line: Now we're really getting somewhere!
Look Doctor, I don't want to appear dim, but how's this going to do the Daleks in?
They think that Lesterson's the driving force, but I don't. The Daleks are using him.
But how?
Problem. Smash the Daleks, and the people here will lock us up or kill us. Let the Daleks go, and we'll all be exterminated.
We could just go back to the Tardis. At least we'd be safe to think there.
Oh yes, it's coming on.
Oh, you talk to him, will you?
Doctor, look, if you told us what you were up to, perhaps we could help you.
Mustn't underestimate any of them. Lesterson's a first class scientist, first class. He opened the capsule. He realised that the Daleks could be reactivated.
Yeah, that could be the answer. Let's kidnap Lesterson, and hide him away for a bit. Well, it would stop him bringing the Daleks back to life, wouldn't it? I thought it was pretty bright.
There we are.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds up the collection of parts he has assembled.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
What is it? It could be the answer to all our problems.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Ben and Polly see Quinn being escorted by a guard.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Examiner, don't let them fool you about the rebels. They're strong. Try and find out where they hold their meetings.
Leave him alone!
It's all right, Polly.
We'll help him Polly, but later.
Yes, but
Now, this is a case where a little injustice is better than wholesale slaughter. What we want is in Lesterson's laboratory. Come along.
Incredible! Let's move on to test fourteen.
I am ready.
When sodium acts on ethyl alcohol, what is the resulting derivative?
Sodium ethoxide. C2 H5 ONA.
Just five seconds, Janley. Just the time it took to speak the answer.
It's right too.
But of course it's right. Look, can you imagine what kind of positronic brain this robot has, Janley? Think of the store of knowledge that it must carry. Sulphuric acid.
H2 SO4.
Ah, you see?
May I come in?
What do you want?
Oh, just to see how you're getting on.
If you think
No, please. I'm not here to cause trouble. I'm just interested, that's all.
You've done nothing but meddle and interfere ever since you landed on Vulcan.
Well, I did give you permission to open up the capsule, now didn't I? Oh please, carry on.
And you won't try to stop me?
Stop you? No, of course not. We got off on the wrong foot, Lesterson, but I'm a reasonable man, and I've been thinking perhaps I was hasty.
Well, if you really want to call a truce.
A truce? My dear fellow, I'd like to be friends.
Yes. Yes, very well, you may stay.
Oh, thank you. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hustles Ben and Polly out of the lab.

Dialogue.Line: Perhaps you'd like to amuse yourselves for a little while.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On the other side of the room, Janley answers the communicator.

Dialogue.Line: Laboratory. Yes. All right. I can come now. Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janley picks up a cloth-wrapped bundle from the desk and conceals it behind her back.

Dialogue.Line: I just have to slip out for a few minutes, Lesterson, all right?
Ah, yes, yes. Very well then, Examiner, shall we test its knowledge of physics?
Oh, splendid, splendid. Please, please, carry on.
Thank you. What is the First Law of Thermodynamics?
When heat is transformed into any other kind of energy or vice versa, the total quantity of energy remains invariable.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the Dalek gives the answer, the Doctor slips the modified control unit from his pocket and connects it to the generator.

Dialogue.Line: That is to say, the quantity of heat which disappears is equivalent to the quantity of other kind of energy produced.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor activates his device and the Dalek begins to spin helplessly, its eye and sucker sticks twitching uncontrollably.

Dialogue.Line: You fool! What do you think you're doing?
I'm saving your life!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lesterson smashes the control unit and pushes the Doctor towards the doors.

Dialogue.Line: Get out! Get out!
I have sustained no damage.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek swings round to watch the Doctor leave, the mechanism behind its empty gun-socket clicking in useless frustration.

Dialogue.Line: It's all right. It's been done.
You were able to get away then?
Yes. Lesterson's with the Examiner. And Hensell?
At a meeting of production managers. He left me in control.
We could take over the colony now.
No. No, it has to be absolutely right. I don't want to take over a colony full of rebels do I, Janley?
I don't know. You're making me help them.
Only to stir them up to create enough trouble to get rid of Hensell, and then, then we crush them. The whole colony will be grateful, and I'll be Governor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janley unwraps the bundle.

Dialogue.Line: Is that the gun you told me of? Can you persuade the rebels this will help them?
Yes, Valmar thinks he can work in a switch to turn it on and off.
How powerful is it?
It killed Resno, Lesterson's assistant. Lesterson believes that Resno's simply shaken up, taking a few days off.
And the body?
In the mercury swamp. Lesterson was the indirect cause of Resno's death. It's a good hold over him if he makes trouble. I'll give this to Valmar then?
Yes.
When do we move?
I need another card in my hand. The Examiner bothers me.
I thought Quinn was the danger.
Not any more. The Examiner's no fool. No, there has to be something else.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A little later, Ben and Polly are searching for the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Well?
Well, he's not in the laboratory. Lesterson's by himself.
Hmm. He must have gone another way. Can I leave it you? I'm going to go back to the rest room.
But
Somebody's got to clear it up.
Okay.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben leaves. Janley appears.

Dialogue.Line: Hello there.
Hello. You're Lesterson's assistant aren't you?
Yes. You're not looking for the Examiner, are you?
Well, do you know where he is?
Yes, he's waiting to get a message through from Earth. He's in the Communications room.
Erm.
Oh, you'll find it easy enough. Look. Around, then to your right, in the next block.
Thanks very much.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janley follows Polly at a short distance.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor? Anyone here?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A technician looms from the shadows and grabs Polly, putting his hand over her mouth.

Dialogue.Line: Well done, Valmar.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janley breaks a phial into a handkerchief.

Dialogue.Line: Hold her. Hold her.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: With the handkerchief over her nose and mouth, Polly sags unconscious in Valmar's arms.

Dialogue.Line: There, that'll keep her quiet for a bit.
I've no idea who she is. She was just snooping around.
I sent her. We want her kept out of the way. Get a couple of your men to keep her in a safe place. Now, this is what I told you about.
Yes. The lethal power must come from here.
Uh huh.
It should have quite a good range.
Can you fix it?
It's easy. This could win us the revolution.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is stretched out on the bed, playing his recorder.

Dialogue.Line: She said she was coming back here. She knew the way, and she wouldn't have wandered off. I know she wouldn't! Oh!
Ben, if you were a Dalek, what would be your next move?
I'm talking about Polly.
Oh, no, no, no, no. She's a clever girl, but she couldn't answer this.
But she is missing!
Oh, no, no, no.
Oh, yes, yes, yes, yes!
No, no, no! She's looking around. There's a lot to see in the colony. She's interested. I like that.
Come on.
Where are we going?
To report it. If we make a fool of ourselves, I don't care. We report it!
Yes, yes, yes. I managed to stop that fool of an Examiner just in time. You know, there are some people here who believe that you're an enemy.
I am your servant. What does this machine do?
You know, it's amazing. You have an almost human interest and curiosity.
A Dalek is bet, is not the same as a human. If I am to help, I must know everything.
Yes. Yes, of course.
What is this machine?
It computes meteorite storms as they approach our weather satellites.
How accurate is it?
About seventy percent. It helps to cut down on our satellite losses.
Daleks can build computers with one hundred percent accuracy.
One hundred percent?
If you provide materials and our own power unit, a computer will be built.
A hundred percent? But that would be an enormous saving for the for the colony.
Then you will get the materials?
I'll go and speak to the Governor at once.
I will be ready to dictate the blueprint when you return.
Oh, that's marvellous.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lesterson leaves. The Dalek moves to the generator and adjusts a control. As the power rises, the Dalek glides inside the capsule.
Ben realises the Doctor is lagging behind.

Dialogue.Line: You agreed we'd go and see Bragen.
Hmm? Power.
Come on then!
Now the energy intake for Daleks should be the cube(The Doctor rips a notice from the notice board, and starts scribbling on the back.)
Now then, twenty two over three. Nineteen times
Well, now what are you at? Talk to yourself.
Oh, it's useless with incomplete data!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor smoothes the notice flat again and pins it back on the board. Then he ducks out of sight.

Dialogue.Line: Lesterson!
Eh?
He just went past. That means we can get into his laboratory again.
But we're looking for
Oh, come along, Ben. Come along.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sees a thick cable stretching from the power unit into the capsule.

Dialogue.Line: There's somebody in there.
What are you doing here?
Stand aside. Servants shouldn't question.
Entry is restricted.
Not for me it isn't. Accord every access. I've got a badge.
That is an order.
A Dalek order. Short circuit the generator, Ben.
Ah! Ah! Ah! Ah! Ah! Stand back!
Don't be frightened of it, Ben. It's not armed. I'm going to see what it was doing in there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor stops as two armed Daleks glide from the capsule.

Dialogue.Line: Ben?
What?
Let's get out of here.
The fool. Lesterson must have reactivated them.
Yes. When I say run, run like a rabbit. Run!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Ben dash the lab.

Dialogue.Line: I have sent the human being for materials. DALEK 2: And power?
Yes. Power we can turn into static. Then we will conquer.
We will conquer. We will conquer. We will conquer.
But if you didn't do it, Lesterson, then the Dalek must have used your power supply and reactivated the others itself.
I was going to do that anyway.
Are you off your head, mate? Those two are armed!
Then we turn off the electricity, disarm them, and then everything is safe again.
But I've already explained to you.
Stop these arguments, both of you. I've had enough. I've every confidence in Lesterson. He has carte blanche for the Daleks from now on.
But they must be destroyed!
Bragen, I'm making a tour of the perimeter. I put you in direct charge here. See that Lesterson gets everything he wants, will you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hensell leaves.

Dialogue.Line: I shall need a permanent guard on my laboratory, Bragen.
Huh.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves, followed by Ben.

Dialogue.Line: Don't worry about the Examiner. I think I can keep him quiet.
We've been forgetting about Polly.
Greed and ambition, that's all it is. Wait till they find out what their precious production figures have cost them!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bragen enters.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, I want to see you.
What about?
Well it's Polly, she's missing. We can't find her anywhere.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor starts playing his recorder.

Dialogue.Line: I'll tell one of my men to make enquiries. It shouldn't take long to find her.
Ah, thanks.
Examiner, some of my men have found a body in the mercury swamp. It was the body of a middle-aged man.
What is that to do with me?
You're the Examiner. Or maybe you're not.
Just exactly what do you mean by that?
Who are you? Quinn's friends come to stir up rebellion?
There's only one possible way that you could know I'm not the Examiner.
Yeah, by knowing what the real Examiner looked like.
Exactly, Ben. Exactly! Only two people knew of his arrival on this planet. Myself and his murderer.
That's enough!
Is it? Doctor, we've got to tell the Governor.
Do you think he'll believe you? I'll soon convince him that you murdered the man yourself. You stole the Examiner's badge.
Then why don't you arrest us? Because there's a doubt isn't there? Because it might, it just might, go against you.
All right, all right, so neither of us wants to make a move. But you leave Lesterson alone. And the Daleks!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bragen leaves.

Dialogue.Line: He'd make a right Father Christmas, wouldn't he?
Oh, I'd rather fight a hundred of his sort than just one Dalek.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An envelope is pushed under the door. Ben opens the door but the corridor is empty. Ben picks up the letter.

Dialogue.Line: Listen to this. The girl is safe. She will remain so as long as you leave the Daleks alone.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the Daleks close in, Lesterson goes to the generator and cuts the power supply. Instantly, the Daleks movements become sluggish.

Dialogue.Line: (slow) Turn back the power supply.
I will, I will. But I want you to remember that I control you.
We are your servants.
I know. Remember it. I gave you each a special charge to bring you back to life. Any further power you need must come from this generator, and I control it. Is that clear?
We obey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lesterson returns the generator to full power. Two of the Daleks return to the capsule.

Dialogue.Line: Where are they going?
To await your orders, master.
Good. Have you completed the blueprints for the meteor storm computer?
It is ready.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They go to a table.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's marvellous! I'm glad we understand each other.
We understand the human mind.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bragen is dressed in the uniform of a Deputy Governor now. Valmar is repairing the communications desk.

Dialogue.Line: Isn't that finished yet?
Nearly. This is Valmar. Test call please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The communicator buzzes.

Dialogue.Line: Terrace. So I can hear you clearly all right, good. Now try and get in connection now with the interior, and then the perimeter stations. Well, no troubles now.
About time. This work should have been completed long before this.
Well, I did the best I could.
Well, it isn't good enough.
Then get someone else, Bragen.
Be careful. I shall be watching you, Valmar, after this. Now get out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's a commotion outside.

Dialogue.Line: See Bragen.
Accord every access.
What does this intrusion mean?
I'm sorry, Bragen. I tried to stop them.
Intrusion? It's no intrusion. We're just returning the various calls that you made. This guard tried to tell us you were busy. You're not a bit, are you?
All right, I'll see them.
Oh, what a nice new uniform. Very smart, very smart. I would like a hat like that.
Well, what do you want?
Some joker has kidnapped Polly and sent us this note.
Yes.
Well, we want to know what you're doing to find her.
Now that the communications are restored we can start a search.
Yeah, I can just imagine what kind of job you'll make of that. Haven't you heard anything yet?
The planet is a large one.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Dalek enters, carrying a drink on a tray.

Dialogue.Line: So, they've given you the run of the colony, have they?
We obey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor picks up a chair as if to defend himself.

Dialogue.Line: Do I bring liquid for your visitors?
No. They won't be staying much longer.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Look, Doctor, if he's not going to help us, we'll have to search for Polly ourselves.
Sound advice. Why don't you, Doctor?
Uh, uh. Examiner. I wonder how much longer they'll be able to move around on these floors?
Ay?
The floors. They're not metal.
Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Ben leave. The video communicator on the desk flashes on.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, there you are Bragen. Thank heavens the communications are working again. It's bad enough being stuck out here on the perimeter. Well? Your report, man. Hurry up. I've got a very full schedule.
There is nothing to report, Governor. HENSELL [on monitor]: The Examiner?
I'm taking good care of him. HENSELL [on monitor]: Good, you know my orders.
Yes, sir. HENSELL [on monitor]: All right. Well, you can reach me here if you have to, that's all.
One moment, Governor. When will you be coming back? HENSELL [on monitor]: Oh, not for a day or two at least. You can manage, can't you?
Yes. Yes, of course, Governor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek has returned.

Dialogue.Line: What do you want?
Have you finished your liquid?
No. No, I haven't.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janley is pinning a new sign to the notice board. Moving on, she meets Kebble and sends him to the board.

Dialogue.Line: You'd better check the agenda.
I'll do it now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kebble hurries away as the Doctor and Ben approach.

Dialogue.Line: Static, do you see. They need a constant supply of static from the floor. Some sort of electrical field.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben sees Kebble leaving.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor. Why should he?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Three Daleks go past.

Dialogue.Line: It's madness!
What is?
Letting them run around like this.
Hey, wait a minute. Bragen had one acting as a servant, and we've just left him.
One Dalek in Bragen's office. Three Daleks just gone down the corridors. That makes four.
Where did the fourth one come from?
Well, Lesterson can't have been making them. Perhaps there were more in the capsule than we thought.
We must go and see Lesterson. Yeah, and show him this note. Maybe he or Janley knows where Polly is.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gazes at the notice board. Kebble comes back then turns away again when he sees Ben.

Dialogue.Line: We frightened him off. I wonder what the fascination of this notice board is?
It looks like a perfectly ordinary notice board to me.
Yeah, well, come on, Doctor. We must find out who's got Polly. Doctor, come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor follows Ben. Kebble returns.

Dialogue.Line: Janley?
What is it?
The Daleks. They've given me another list of materials they need.
Let me see. We've got all those things?
Yes, but why these quantities, Janley? Why? How can they have used up all the materials I gave them? What is it? Why, it's only a matter of a few hours ago.
They're building new things for us.
Yes, well, I don't want them to do anything without consulting me. What is it they do inside there?
You're worrying too much.
Look, Janley, say what you like, but I'm beginning to believe that the Examiner is right about the Daleks. Their original thinking terrifies me. If we can control them, fine. But if not
Yes?
Then I shall have them destroyed. It's too dangerous. The Examiner knows something about them that we don't. I'm going to ask his advice.
I wouldn't bring the Examiner into it if I were you.
And why not?
You want him to find out about Resno?
Oh, a little accident. How is he? Is he better?
He's dead.
What are you talking about? You told me he was
You were busy with the experiments on the Daleks.
But you should have told me. But the body? It'll have to be reported.
Don't worry, no one will find the body.
Oh, Janley, you've done a terrible thing.
The experiments on the Daleks were more important.
More important than human life? No, no, I won't accept that.
You will. You must. Your carelessness was the cause of Resno's death. You murdered him. It's only your word against mine.
I won't be blackmailed by you.
All I want is for you to go on as you are. Scientific discovery can't stop dead, Lesterson.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Ben enter.

Dialogue.Line: I told the guard that no-one was to be allowed in.
Accord every access, remember?
We're looking for Polly.
Well, she isn't here, and I haven't seen her.
Well, she's been kidnapped.
Oh, it sounds a little unlikely.
Oh, it does, does it? Well, we've got this note which tells us so.
I'm very sorry, but I don't know anything about it.
Lesterson?
Yes?
You haven't been building Daleks, have you?
Building? No, I wouldn't know how to begin.
And there were only three in the capsule?
Yes.
Well, we've just seen four. One in the Governor's office and three in the corridor.
But that's not possible!
There's only one explanation. The Daleks are reproducing themselves.
These things are machines. How could they reproduce?
Machines? What makes you think they're just machines? The Daleks are brilliant engineers. Nothing is beyond them given the right materials.
What?
I said nothing is beyond them given the right materials.
Oh.
Lesterson, what's the matter?
Oh.
Leave him alone. He's just been overworking, that's all.
Well, he looks bad.
Will you both go away. Guard! It's you, badgering him with questions. You've done nothing but hound him ever since you arrived on Vulcan. Bragen's orders were that no one was to be admitted.
Yes, but I thought that the Examiner.
He attacked Lesterson. Get them out of here. Both of them.
He did not attack Lesterson!
Out, do you hear?
All right, all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard leads the Doctor and Ben out. Janley uses the communications unit.

Dialogue.Line: Janley here. Tell Valmar to come over to the lab right away. Good. Now, it's all right. Come on. Rest here for a bit. There. You've been doing far too much.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janley gives Lesterson a glass of water.

Dialogue.Line: Shh.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: When Valmar arrives, Lesterson is fast asleep.

Dialogue.Line: I've sedated him.
Well, what's the matter with him?
Overwork, I suppose. He just suddenly broke up. Anyway, it'll give you a chance to lay in the new power cable the Daleks have asked for.
You don't miss a trick, do you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janley goes to the Dalek capsule.

Dialogue.Line: We're going to lay in the new cables you wanted.
Good.
You're sure this is okay, Janley?
Of course. We help them, they help us.
Yes. We are your servants.
Don't take too long about it, Valmar. Oh, you saw the notice, did you?
I saw it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Back at the notice board.

Dialogue.Line: Well, we're still no nearer finding Polly. What are we hanging about here for?
Ben, I've found a message in code. It's an anagram, you just take the capital letters, see? Work it out yourself.
Oh, I can't do crosswords.
Meeting tonight, 2000 hours. R O C K E T -- Rocket. R O O M - Room. P. Rocket Room P.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor lets a Dalek go past.

Dialogue.Line: It's the rebel's way of calling a meeting. Only tonight we're going to be there, early.
Yeah, maybe we're nearer finding Polly than I thought.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Later, the Doctor and Ben are hiding behind a pile of boxes.

Dialogue.Line: Ow. I've got pins and needles now.
What's the time?
Time we went home.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The rebels start filing into the room, taking their places around a large table. Valmar brings a Dalek in. Janley has a Dalek gun-stick attached to a control box. Valmar fastens the gun-stick to the Dalek.

Dialogue.Line: Now, we're going to demonstrate something. You section leaders can pass on what you've seen. So far, we've been concerned with testing the strength of the Governor with a few acts of sabotage. But now we're ready to take over.
What is that thing? I've seen them moving about, but all we've been told is that it's a machine Lesterson discovered.
Valmar.
Lesterson removed the armaments of the Daleks he discovered. I've rearmed this one, but with a controlling device. We can regulate the fire power and turn it off and on whenever we choose.
Shall we have the demonstration now?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A shadowy figure nods.

Dialogue.Line: That's the one we want. He must be the boss of this outfit.
This screen is two inch thick tungsten steel. Right, Valmar.
Fire at the screen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The metal screen is totally destroyed. Consternation.

Dialogue.Line: Quiet! You must keep quiet. We're too vulnerable here.
But you can't control a thing like that. It'll turn on us.
No, it won't.
I wouldn't let any of my group go anywhere near it.
I can control it.
Prove it. Ah, you daren't! I'm not talking about that thing firing at the wall or bits of metal or anything. I mean people. Have you tested whether you can stop it from killing people? Our people?
Look, I can show you what I've done here.
Forget it. How do you know a Dalek can tell the difference between the Governor's people and our people?
But I can tell the difference, you fool, and I control it.
We want something better than words.
Test it on me. Will that satisfy you?
Well yes, but
She's out of her mind.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Valmar looks at the man in the shadows.

Dialogue.Line: Is it all right?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man agrees. Janley stands in front of the Dalek.

Dialogue.Line: Now, when I tell you to fire
I am your servant.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Valmar flicks a switch, and taps the Dalek on its dome. The weapon does no damage.

Dialogue.Line: Get back to your places.
Are you all right?
Of course. I don't take needless risks.
Oh, well done, Janley.
You haven't disarmed the Dalek. Well, go on, take the gun away. We don't want any accidents. Now, what about the girl?
We've got her safely locked up. Never fear.
I think the best thing for us to do is
Hear that? Maybe they'll say were she is.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben sends a box crashing to the floor.

Dialogue.Line: Who's there?
You stay there, I'll distract them. Find out where Polly is.
No!
Help! Help!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben runs out and Kebble grabs him and knocks him out.

Dialogue.Line: The guards will have heard that! Come on we've got to get out of here! Take him and lock him up! Quick! Out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kebble and another man drag Ben away. Janley and the rebels follow, leaving the leader and the Dalek in the room.

Dialogue.Line: You might as well come out. We know you're there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek goes to the Doctor's hiding place.

Dialogue.Line: Bragen.
Of course. Who else is fitted to be leader of the rebels?
No doubt you want to be leader of the Daleks too.
I am the leader of the Daleks.
Well, see if you can stop this one from killing me.
Stop! You heard me, that's an order. Turn away. Fetch the guard.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek hesitates.

Dialogue.Line: I obey.
You hope to have it both ways, Bragen. But how will you look in front of the Governor, when I explain your dual role to him?
The Governor will hardly listen to an impostor.
An impostor? How do you propose to prove that?
My guards are now going to produce the body of the real Examiner from the mercury swamp.
The one you murdered.
The one you pretended to be.
Murder's a far worse crime than impersonation.
Yes, but you can't prove I'm a murderer, while I can prove that you're an impostor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek returns with Janley and two guards.

Dialogue.Line: Take this man away. Detain him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards escort the Doctor out.

Dialogue.Line: A dangerous man.
Now the only one left is the Governor.
Perhaps we should have dealt with the Examiner earlier.
I'll deal with him in time, and Quinn.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A guard uses a sonic key to open the cell next to Quinn, put the Doctor inside and relock it. The guards leave.

Dialogue.Line: You're the last man I expected to see here.
Hmm. Works by sound, does it?
I'm speaking to you, Examiner.
Oh, I'm sorry.
If you'd listened to me in the first place, you wouldn't be locked up here now.
Well, your imprisonment hasn't been entirely wasted. It's brought your enemy out into the open.
Bragen? I've known that all along.
Yes. But did you know that he was the leader of the rebels?
Bragen, the leader?
Yes. It's quite a simple sort of lock, really.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor empties his pockets.

Dialogue.Line: Hensell's trouble is he thinks he can run this colony on his personality alone.
But even if he knew of the danger, could he do anything? The rebels are well organised.
The Governor's popular. He can count on the mine workers at the perimeter for support.
In that case we must get word to him.
If you'd done your job properly, Examiner, you wouldn't be here now, and I'd have been out too.
Ah yes, but then I'm not the real Examiner.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor chooses a dog whistle from his collection.

Dialogue.Line: Ben, Polly and I, we're just travellers, that's all. I found the Examiner dead. Bragen murdered him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor blows the high pitched whistle at the lock.

Dialogue.Line: Everything leads back friend Bragen. Just give me a chance get my hands on him.
We aren't going to have that chance unless we can get out of here.
There's just a little matter of the cell doors.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The doors don't open, but a dog starts barking outside.
Lesterson wakes. He gets a wet handkerchief and presses it to his face. A Dalek enters and he hides. It goes to the capsule and another Dalek comes out.

Dialogue.Line: You sent for me?
Take up a position at the communications room. Watch and report. DALEK 2: I obey.
They're conspiring together! Oh, why didn't I realise? The Examiner was right. They are evil!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two more Daleks come out of the capsule and all three leave.

Dialogue.Line: There are four. They can't be reproducing!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lesterson closes the capsule door, then drags a heavy cabinet in front of it. Janley enters.

Dialogue.Line: What's the matter? What is it? Are you ill?
They're in there, making themselves! Duplicating!
What? What are you talking about?
I started this, opening the capsule.
Lesterson!
Don't try to stop me!
What happened?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The generator is turned off.

Dialogue.Line: They forget that I control them. I gave them life back again, and now I've taken it away. Finished it, stopped it.
The Daleks?
Evil. Horrible. I know what I'm going to do. Laser torches. Melt them down. I'm going to melt the Daleks down to pools of metal.
You won't, Lesterson.

Oh, do you think I care what you can do? Go on, tell everybody I was responsible for Resno's death. I don't care! I'm going to wipe out the Daleks! Yes, tell everybody all about me! I'm still going to I'm going to wipe out the Daleks!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janley leaves. Lesterson lifts the communications receiver.

Dialogue.Line: Get me the Examiner. Prison? Who put him there? But I've got to talk to him! I've got to, don't you understand?(The capsule door opens, pushing the cabinet aside. A Dalek moves up behind Lesterson.)
How did you get there? I cut off the power.
We can store power. We will soon have our own.
Own power?
Why was the capsule door closed?
Own power! Argh!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lesterson flees. Another Dalek enters.

Dialogue.Line: Seal off the capsule's secret entrance. DALEK 2: I obey.
Wait! No more than three Daleks to be seen together at any one time. DALEK 2: I obey.
We are not ready yet to teach these human beings the law of the Daleks.
You can help me!
What's the matter?
Where's the Examiner?
The Examiner's in prison.
Oh, yes.
What's the matter with you?
I forgot.
What are you running for? Hey!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janley and Kebble take Polly to the laboratory. A Dalek comes from the capsule.

Dialogue.Line: Did Lesterson come back?
No. Why is this human restricted?
She's against the Daleks. Afraid, are you? Nothing's going to happen to you if you behave.
The Daleks? Of course I'm afraid, and so should you be.
The Daleks are going to help us.
Us being the rebels, I suppose.
If you like.
And when you've won, the Daleks will just go back to being servants again? You're bigger fools than I thought.
We are your servants.
While it suits you.
You'll see.
In!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kebble pushes Polly into the capsule.

Dialogue.Line: You want me to stay with her?
Yes. You may have to help Valmar. He'll be here in a minute to fix up the new Dalek power cable.
Right.
When will the work be completed?
What is this cable you Daleks are laying, anyway?
Daleks operate on static electricity.
Static! Is that possible?
To create static, the Daleks need a complete cable circuit.
I see. You convert our electricity into your own power.
That is correct. When will the human being complete the work?
He'll be here. It's easier now. There's no-one to interfere with our plans.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The dog whistle has not done the trick so the Doctor is running a wet finger around the rim of a glass instead.

Dialogue.Line: Do you have to do that? I'm afraid you'll find these locks are foolproof.
I wonder how they're converting the power?
What are you talking about?
The Daleks. They're powered by static electricity. It's like blood to them, a constant life-stream.
Static isn't workable.
It is to the Daleks. They've conquered static, just as they've conquered anti-magnetics.
I'm not going to listen to any more of this nonsense.
I don't seem to be able to hit the right note. Do you have any more water?
I hope not. No.
Then I shall have to get some.
You can't!
But it's important! It's desperately important!
Well, Bragen gave orders.
Just get out of my way! Ah! Examiner! The Daleks !
Yes?
They're duplicating! I've seen them! They've got their own power now! I can't stop them!
Take him to Bragen.
Oh! Oh! Oh!
I say. I say, do you think we might have a little more water?
Is that all you can say? Lesterson fights his way down here to speak to you and all you can do is demand more water?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard fetches a jug.

Dialogue.Line: Get away from the door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor backs away and listens carefully to the tone of the sonic key. The guard puts down the jug, locks the door and leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Sorry about that outburst. I thought it might help the situation.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor adds a little more water to his glass.

Dialogue.Line: Nearly, nearly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Dalek is laying a cable around the room. Bragen is working at his desk when is brought in Lesterson under guard.

Dialogue.Line: What's this?
He tried to break in and speak with the Examiner.
What is the Dalek doing?!
I thought you knew. Something to do with the emergency power supply.
Oh, no. It's a trick. I didn't ask for it.
Lesterson, I've had reports.
What are you doing?!
Laying the new emergency power supply as you ordered, master.
It's a lie!
I've had reports of your incomprehensible behaviour.
Yes. Yes, but I can explain if you'll get rid of that!
Finish now.
I am your servant.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Where is the Governor?!
At the perimeter. Why?
Call him. Get him back here as quickly as possible. We're all in terrible danger! The Examiner was right! Right all the time!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janley enters.

Dialogue.Line: Don't listen to anything she has to say.
Come along now.
She's in league with the Daleks!
Now, now, now, now. Please, Lesterson. Just take things calmly. You're not well.
I'm perfectly well!
Please, Lesterson, please. Now, you ought to be in hospital. You promised me you'd report there.
I promised nothing of the kind.
Don't you remember? Never mind. I understand.
Pity. It's probably only temporary.
